data.title: Filmmaker Profile
data.meta_description: The Center for Asian American Media (CAAM) is a nonprofit organization dedicated to presenting stories that convey the richness and diversity of Asian American experiences to the broadest audience possible.
data.text:
Jennifer Crystal Chien Joins CAAM and Ninth Street Independent Film Center as a Filmmaker in Residence

Our new filmmaker in residence is working on several projects, including “The Highway,” a short animated documentary recreating a highway protest against police violence.

Linsanity – Five Years Later, “Linsanity” Director Evan Jackson Leong on the Craze that Swept the World

The filmmaker reflects on the 2013 CAAMFest Opening Night film.

“Abacus: Small Enough to Jail” Nominated for an Oscar

The CAAM-funded film has been nominated for Best Documentary Feature.

“Family Ingredients” Producer Heather Haunani Giugni on Representing Hawai’i’s Stories

“My goal has been to be a support, as well as be an example, of a series that can be born and generated here in Hawai’i. Nobody has to go to anywhere else. You don’t have to Hollywood anymore because there is no ‘Hollywood.'”

Q&A with “Hoop Dreams” Director Steve James on “Abacus” Documentary

A new doc looks at why was a small bank serving Chinese immigrants was the only US bank indicted for mortgage fraud related to 2008 crisis.

Justin Chon Gets Personal With “Gook,” His New Film About the L.A. Riots

Chon offers up a graceful, intimate portrait of this unlikely family where race isn’t a theoretical abstraction and where “race relations” aren’t just about clashes on the street.

Q&A with PBS Online Film Festival Director Cyrus Yoshi Tabar

Watch and vote for CAAMFest Loni Ding Award Winner “It Is What It Is!”

“Out Run” Doc on Leader of the World’s Only LGBT Political Party

Bemz Benedito, leader of an LGBT political party, runs to become the first transgender woman in the Philippine Congress. Catch it on World Channel in June and Comcast in July.

Memoirs of a Superfan Vol 12.12: Steve James, the Sung family and “Abacus” Documentary

Abacus is an intimate look at the Sung family’s resolve as their bank serving predominantly the Chinese immigrant community in New York City became the only bank prosecuted after the 2008 Great Recession.

The Ecstasy of the Ephemeral: Mira Nair Brings Monsoon Wedding to the Stage

“I have always taken courage in my distinctive community. I want to see our names, our voices, our dreams, our struggles—that is what I am devoted to.”

Grace Lee’s ‘K-TOWN ‘92’ Tells a Different Story of the LA Riots

To Lee, the days of unrest also brought Korean America to mainstream consciousness like nothing before it. NOW STREAMING ON PBS!
